H0.text: Oxygen is the gas B in the cycle in which a tree uses gas A to produce gas B, and an animal uses gas B to produce gas A.

H1.text: Nitrogen is the gas that a tree produces from gas A and that an animal uses to produce gas A in this cycle.

H2.text: Carbon dioxide is the gas B that a tree produces from gas A and that an animal uses to produce gas A in this cycle.

H3.text: Carbon monoxide is gas B in this cycle, where a tree uses gas A to produce carbon monoxide and an animal uses carbon monoxide to produce gas A.

A4.text: Oxygen is a waste product of light-dependent reactions, but the majority of organisms on Earth use oxygen and its energy for cellular respiration, including photosynthetic organisms.

A5.text: In plants, algae, and cyanobacteria, sugars are synthesized by a subsequent sequence of light-independent reactions called the Calvin cycle. In this process, atmospheric carbon dioxide is incorporated into already existing organic compounds, such as ribulose bisphosphate (RuBP).

A6.text: Oxygen is a waste product of light-dependent reactions
